hints.content:
###Strategy

We can count the number of groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ from the diagram. Since $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ is less than $1$, we will expect to find more than $1$ group.

The expression $\purpleD{7}\div \blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ can mean, "How many groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ are in $\purpleD{7}$?" There will be $\purpleD{7}$ times as many groups in $\purpleD{7}$ as there were in $1$.

###Counting the groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ in $1$

Since there are $8$ eighths per $1$ unit, there are between $2$ and $3$ full groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ in $1$. 

It takes $3$ parts for each full group, and there are $2$ parts left over, for a total of $8$ out of $3$ parts.

[[☃ image 1]]

There are exactly $\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{3}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ in $1$. 

We call $\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{3}}$ the **reciprocal** of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}}$.

options.alt: A number line from 0 to 10 eighths with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1 eighth.  0 and 1 are labeled below the number line.  0 eighths, 1 eighth, 2 eighths, 3 eighths, 4 eighths, 5 eighths, 6 eighths, 7 eighths, 8 eighths, 9 eighths, and 10 eighths are labeled above the number line.  There is a teal line on the number line that begins at 0 and ends at 3 eighths.  There is an orange line on the number line that begins at 3 eighths and ends at 6 eighths. There is another teal line on the number line that begins at 6 eighths and ends at 1.  Above the number line is a fraction model with 9 equal parts.  5 parts are shaded teal, 3 parts are shaded orange, and 1 part is white. The number of color blocks of the fraction model correspond to the length of the colored sections on the number line. 8 thirds groups of 3 eighths is above the fraction model with a bracket that starts at the first part of the fraction model and ending after the eighth part of the fraction model.

hints.content:
###Finding the groups of $\dfrac{3}{8}$ in $\purpleD{7}$

There are $\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{3}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ in $1$. 

So there are $\purpleD{7}\times \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{3}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ in $\purpleD{7}$.

$\begin{align}
\purpleD{7}\div \blueE{\dfrac{3}{8}} &= \purpleD{7} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{3}}\\\\
&= \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{1}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{3}}\\\\
&= \goldE{\dfrac{56}{3}}
\end{align}$

question.content:
Use the number line to answer the following $2$ questions.

[[☃ image 1]]

1. **How many groups of $\dfrac{3}{8}$ are in $1$?**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] groups

2. **Evaluate.**

$7\div \dfrac{3}{8}=$ [[☃ numeric-input 2]]

There is a teal line on the number line that begins at 0 and ends at 3 eighths.  There is an orange line on the number line that begins at 3 eighths and ends at 6 eighths. There is another teal line on the number line that begins at 6 eighths and ends at 1.  Above the number line is a fraction model with 9 equal parts.  5 parts are shaded teal, 3 parts are shaded orange, and 1 part is white. The number of color blocks of the fraction model correspond to the length of the colored sections on the number line.

hints.content:
###Strategy

We can count the number of groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ from the diagram. Since $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ is less than $1$, we will expect to find more than $1$ group.

The expression $\purpleD{8}\div \blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ can mean, "How many groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ are in $\purpleD{8}$?" There will be $\purpleD{8}$ times as many groups in $\purpleD{8}$ as there were in $1$.

###Counting the groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $1$

Since there are $7$ sevenths per $1$ unit, there are between $1$ and $2$ full groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $1$. 

It takes $5$ parts for each full group, and there are $2$ parts left over, for a total of $7$ out of $5$ parts.

[[☃ image 1]]

There are exactly $\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $1$. 

We call $\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}$ the **reciprocal** of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$.

Above the number line is a fraction model with 10 equal parts.  5 parts are shaded teal, 2 parts are shaded orange, and 3 parts are white. hints.content:
###Finding the groups of $\dfrac{5}{7}$ in $\purpleD{8}$

There are $\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $1$. 

So there are $\purpleD{8}\times \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $\purpleD{8}$.

$\begin{align}
\purpleD{8}\div \blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}} &= \purpleD{8} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}\\\\
&= \purpleD{\dfrac{8}{1}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}\\\\
&= \goldE{\dfrac{56}{5}}
\end{align}$

hints.content:
###Strategy

We can count the number of groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ from the diagram. Since $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ is less than $1$, we will expect to find more than $1$ group.

The expression $\purpleD{5}\div \blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ can mean, "How many groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ are in $\purpleD{5}$?" There will be $\purpleD{5}$ times as many groups in $\purpleD{5}$ as there were in $1$.

###Counting the groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ in $1$

Since there are $4$ fourths per $1$ unit, there are between $1$ and $2$ full groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ in $1$. 

It takes $3$ parts for each full group, and there is $1$ part left over, for a total of $4$ out of $3$ parts.

[[☃ image 1]]

There are exactly $\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{3}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ in $1$. 

We call $\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{3}}$ the **reciprocal** of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$.

There is a teal line on the number line that begins at 0 and ends at 3 fourths.  There is an orange line on the number line that begins at 3 fourths and ends at 1.  Above the number line is a fraction model with 6 equal parts.  3 parts are shaded teal, 1 part is shaded orange, and 2 parts are white. The number of color blocks of the fraction model correspond to the length of the colored sections on the number line. 4 thirds groups of 3 fourths is above the fraction model with a bracket that starts at the first part of the fraction model and ending after the fourth part of the fraction model.

hints.content:
###Finding the groups of $\dfrac{3}{4}$ in $\purpleD{5}$

There are $\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{3}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ in $1$. 

So there are $\purpleD{5}\times \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{3}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ in $\purpleD{5}$.

$\begin{align}
\purpleD{5}\div \blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}} &= \purpleD{5} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{3}}\\\\
&= \purpleD{\dfrac{5}{1}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{3}}\\\\
&= \goldE{\dfrac{20}{3}}
\end{align}$
